1090410.1007/10904.1574-1451Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-013-0015-71510.1007/s10904-013-0015-7ArticleA 3D Porous Coordination Polymer from Tetrazole Ligand and Cd(II): Crystal Structure, Luminescent Property and Adsorption of Methanol and WaterLiBo13YuKai12bWangChunmei12SuZhanhua12WangChunxiao12ZhouBaibin12fgrid.411991.50000000104947769Key Laboratory for Photonic and Electronic Bandgap Materials, Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringHarbin Normal University150025HarbinPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.411991.50000000104947769Key Laboratory of Synthesis of Functional Materials and Green Catalysis, Colleges of Heilongjiang ProvinceHarbin Normal University150025HarbinPeople’s Republic of ChinaDepartment of ChemistryHeihe College164300HeihePeople’s Republic of Chinahlyukai188@163.com+86-451-88060173zhou_bai_bin@163.com20122013520142435255301012201329920131012201320122013© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20132013Abstract

An unusual tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymer, [Cd(4-tzba)(H2O)]n (tzba = 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid) (1), was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The structure of 1 contains distorted octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four different tzba2− ligands and a water molecule. All the tzba2− ligands display coordination of type, μ4-κN1:κN3:κN4:κO1, O2, which connects four Cd(II) atoms to form an intricate 3-D network. There are three kinds of apertures in the structure of 1; two helical channels and a hexagonal aperture are observed along different axes. Polymer 1 exhibits selective gas adsorption behavior for methanol, ethanol and water. In addition, 1 shows blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of the aromatic rings in the tbza2− ligand.

Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great interest not only due to fascinating structural topologies but also for their potential applications in catalysis [1], hydrogen storage [2, 3], adsorption [4, 5], luminescent function [6, 7], magnetism [8], and biomedicine [9]. Construction of desired MOF-extended assemblies involves the selection and design of appropriate organic bridging ligands and metal-connecting nodes. On one hand, organic ligands play crucial roles in the construction of MOFs because changes in flexibility, length and symmetry of the organic ligands can dramatically influence microstructure and the character of resulting coordination polymer [10–20]. Bifunctional organic ligands such as 5-substituted tetrazoles-carboxylates comprise four N-atoms in the tetrazolate and two O-atoms in the carboxyl as potential binding center. These can serve as excellent multidentate ligands and can display complicated coordination modes. Recently, a number of MOFs based on a variety of tetrazoles ligands have been reported [21–29]. However, in contrast to tetrazolate-5-carboxylate coordination polymers composed of acyclic spacers, research on aromatic spacer-containing ligands remains quite rare. For example, 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid ligand-modified MOFs (Scheme S1) are relatively undeveloped. To our knowledge, only rare examples of such coordination polymers have been reported [27, 30]. Thus, 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid simultaneously possesses a rigid and multidentate character (Scheme 1) and may induce new MOFs microporous materials with fascinating architectures [31–35].

Transition metal Cd(II) ions, due to their relatively strong coordination ability to both O- and N-atoms and various coordination numbers, have been widely used as metal-connecting nodes to construct MOFs. In addition, cadmium ions are excellent candidates for photoluminescence owing to its d [10] electronic configuration [23, 36, 37]. These potential applications further stimulated our interest in the species of the Cd-based MOFs compounds. Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structure and luminescent property of a novel 3D open microporous MOF with multi-shaped channel; i.e., [Cd(tzba)(H2O)] (1). Additionally, the adsorption of methanol, ethanol and water is measured.

ExperimentalMaterials and Measurements

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded from 400 to 4,000 cm−1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer as pressed KBr pellets. Thermogravimetry (TGA) was performed with a Perkin–Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) were collected with a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer using graphite monochromatized CuKα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ from 5 to 50°. The photoluminescent properties were measured with a FLSP920 Edinburgh Fluorescence Spectrometer. The vapor adsorption measurements were performed with an Autosorb-iQ2-MP-AG.

Synthesis

Compound 1 was prepared by the hydrothermal method: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.1542 g, 0.50 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol), tzba (0.0951 g, 0.5 0 mmol), and deionized water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30-min, then transferred and sealed in a 25 mLTelfon-lined reactor and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water. (yield 30 % based on Cd). Anal. calcd (%) for C8H4CdN4O3: C, 30.35; H, 1.27; N, 17.70; Cd, 35.51. Found: C, 30.37; H, 1.28; N, 17.74; Cd, 35.56.

X-Ray Crystallography

The structure of 1 was determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Intensity data were collected with a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier map with the SHELXL-97 program [38, 39] and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms on C- and N-atoms of the organic ligands were included in the calculated positions. Hydrogen atoms attached to the –OH group and lattice water molecules were found from the difference Fourier maps. The crystallographic data and structural determination of 1 are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are listed in Table S1.

Results and DiscussionStructure

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the P21/c space group and exhibits a 3D network joined by the Cd(II) centers and tzba2− ligands. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Cd atom, one tzba2− ligand and one water molecule (Figs. 1, S1). The environment around the six-coordinated Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron with N3B, N4C, O1, and O2 atoms from three different tzba2− ligands constituting the equatorial plane. The axial sites are occupied by water O-atoms (O3) and N1A atoms from the fourth tzba2− ligands with O(3)–Cd(1)–N(1) angle of 169.56(6). The Cd–O bond lengths range from 2.2227(18) to 2.4797(17) Å ; and, the Cd–N bond lengths are 2.3252(17) and 2.3724(18) Å, respectively. All the tzba2− ligands display a type of coordination, μ4-κN1: κN3: κN4: κO1, O2, to connect four Cd(II) atoms with carboxylate group in a bidentate chelating mode and a tetrazolate group in a 1,2,4-N mode. Interestingly, this μ4—bridging mode for the tzba2− ligand is different from those of structurally related tzf2− or tza2− ligands, [40, 41] which was first found in Cd(II) complexes.

As shown in Fig. 2a, each tetrazolate group of tzba2− ligand is linked to three Cd(II) atoms and each Cd(II) atom is coordinated to adjacent three tetrazolate groups to form a layer along the bc plane (Fig. 2a), in which two Cd(II) atoms are connected by two tetrazolate groups to form a dimeric cluster; i.e., {Cd(tetrazole)}2 units. The adjacent dimeric units are bonded together in ABAB mode via Cd–N bonds. Moreover, the adjacent dimeric layers are further aggregated through phenylcarboxylate groups along the ac side (Fig. 2b). Thus, the overall structure of 1 may be described as adjacent dimeric {Cd(tetrazole)}2 layers that are further supported by the phenylcarboxylate groups to yield intricate 3-D network structure.

Note that 1 is a unique 4,4-connected three-dimensional framework with an unprecedented topology (Fig. 3). In this simplification, the green 4-connected nodes are Cd(II) centers and the black are the 4-connected tzba2− ligand. The distances between the connected nodes are 4.314, 4.903, 5.561, and 7.090 Å. Furthermore, the Cd(II) centers are connected by tzba2− ligands to form a 3D open framework with multi-channels (Figs. 4, 5). The helical channels A and B are observed along the a axis, in which {Cd(tetrazole)}4 clusters and double phenylcarboxylate groups are intertwisted in an alternating fashion to form the A channels. The B channel appears to have an 18-membered aperture. In fact, there is no closed 18-membered present in the structure. The unclosed Cd–tetrazole and Cd–tzba are linked to give rise to right-handed helices (Fig. 4). The screw pitch of the helix is 12.48 Å. The C Channels have a 6-membered aperture that are stacked in hexagonal configurations of approximately 8.158 × 5.810 Å along the crystallographic b axis (with Cd1–Cd1 distances of 8.158 and N3–N3 5.810 Å) (Fig. 5).

IR Absorption Spectrometry

The IR spectrum of the 1 is shown in Fig. S2. The band at 3,343 cm−1 is assigned to the OH stretching vibration of the carboxyl group. The characteristic band at 1,700 cm−1 is assigned to the νC=O stretching vibration. The band at 1,600 cm−1 is attributed to νC=C in the carboxyl group; and, the band at 1,348 cm−1 is assigned to νC–O. Bands at 1,525 cm−1 and 1,420 cm−1 belong to the tetrazolate ring and the band at 682 cm−1 is the out-of-plane swing vibration of benzene ring and hydrogen [23].

TGA

To study the thermal stability of 1, TGA was performed (Fig. S3). There are two weight-loss steps from 25 to 800 °C. The first weight-loss (5.4 %) from 60 to 250 °C corresponds to the release of one coordinated water (calcd. 5.69 %). The second weight-loss step (58.82 %) from 400 to 800 °C is attributed to the loss of a tzba ligand (calcd. 58.80 %).

PXRD Patterns

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of 1 is shown in Fig. S4. The peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD pattern at 20 °C are in agreement, which suggests a good phase purity for 1.

Fluorescent Property

The solid-state luminescence for 1 was carried out at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the 1 is depicted in Fig. S5. Polymer 1 exhibits a strong blue photoluminescence with emission maxima at 428 nm upon excitations at 376 nm. This is a red shift with respect to the free ligand, H2tzba (λem = 327 nm with excitation at 300 nm [27]). Other tetrazolate-based complexes, such as [Mn(4-TZBA2−)(H2O)2] and [Mn4(4-TZBA2−)4(μ2-H2O)2(H2O) (py)], are bathochromically shifted to 434 nm (excitation at 361 nm) and 425 nm (excitation at 358 nm), respectively. The photoluminescent mechanism is attributed to a ligand-centered π–π* excitation mainly through the aromatic rings of tbza2−, which is characteristic of fluorescent emissions for Cd(II) complexes with other heterocyclic aromatic ligands [24]. The results suggest that the polymer may be used as a blue light-emitting material [1].

Sorption Properties

The porosity of 1 was estimated by methanol, ethanol and water gas adsorption isotherms at 298 K. As shown in Fig. 6, 1 exhibits Type-I behavior with a small hysteresis to water and methanol. The amount of water and methanol uptake increases with an increase in P/P0 and reaches 165 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.86. The saturated sorption amount of water is equivalent to the adsorption of about 5.8 mmol g−1. The sorption amount reaches 120 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.9, which is equivalent to the adsorption of about 4.4 mmol g−1. In contrast, the amount of ethanol sorption (2.3 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.9) is close to the surface adsorption and is negligible, which indicates that methanol cannot easily enter the channel. Polymer 1 can adsorb water and methanol molecules, but excludes the larger ethanol molecules. The above adsorption studies show that 1 is a promising material for separating methanol and water from bioethanol. Significant hysteresis between adsorption and desorption traces indicates a microporous material [1].

Conclusion

A novel microporous coordination polymer, [Cd(tbza)(H2O)]n (1), with aromatic spacer-containing ligand tbza2− was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The structure of 1 contains octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four tbza2− ligands to form infinite 3D open framework with multi-channels. Polymer 1 exhibits remarkable selective adsorption behavior; e.g., adsorbs water and methanol, but excludes ethanol. This indicates that 1 is a good porous material for separating both methanol and water from bioethanol. Polymer 1 also displays strong blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of aromatic rings in tbza2− ligand.

Crystallographic and Supplementary Information

CCDC 881998 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. The data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The vapor adsorption measurements were performed with an Autosorb-iQ2-MP-AG.SynthesisCompound 1 was prepared by the hydrothermal method: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.1542 g, 0.50 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol), tzba (0.0951 g, 0.5 0 mmol), and deionized water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30-min, then transferred and sealed in a 25 mLTelfon-lined reactor and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water. (yield 30 % based on Cd). Anal. calcd (%) for C8H4CdN4O3: C, 30.35; H, 1.27; N, 17.70; Cd, 35.51. Found: C, 30.37; H, 1.28; N, 17.74; Cd, 35.56.X-Ray CrystallographyThe structure of 1 was determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Intensity data were collected with a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier map with the SHELXL-97 program [38, 39] and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms on C- and N-atoms of the organic ligands were included in the calculated positions. Hydrogen atoms attached to the -OH group and lattice water molecules were found from the difference Fourier maps. The crystallographic data and structural determination of 1 are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are listed in Table S1.Results and DiscussionStructureSingle crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the P21/c space group and exhibits a 3D network joined by the Cd(II) centers and tzba2- ligands. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Cd atom, one tzba2- ligand and one water molecule (Figs. 1, S1). The environment around the six-coordinated Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron with N3B, N4C, O1, and O2 atoms from three different tzba2- ligands constituting the equatorial plane. The axial sites are occupied by water O-atoms (O3) and N1A atoms from the fourth tzba2- ligands with O(3)-Cd(1)-N(1) angle of 169.56(6). The Cd-O bond lengths range from 2.2227(18) to 2.4797(17) Å ; and, the Cd-N bond lengths are 2.3252(17) and 2.3724(18) Å, respectively. All the tzba2- ligands display a type of coordination, μ4-κN1: κN3: κN4: κO1, O2, to connect four Cd(II) atoms with carboxylate group in a bidentate chelating mode and a tetrazolate group in a 1,2,4-N mode. Interestingly, this μ4-bridging mode for the tzba2- ligand is different from those of structurally related tzf2- or tza2- ligands, [40, 41] which was first found in Cd(II) complexes.As shown in Fig. 2a, each tetrazolate group of tzba2- ligand is linked to three Cd(II) atoms and each Cd(II) atom is coordinated to adjacent three tetrazolate groups to form a layer along the bc plane (Fig. 2a), in which two Cd(II) atoms are connected by two tetrazolate groups to form a dimeric cluster; i.e., {Cd(tetrazole)}2 units. The adjacent dimeric units are bonded together in ABAB mode via Cd-N bonds. Moreover, the adjacent dimeric layers are further aggregated through phenylcarboxylate groups along the ac side (Fig. 2b). Thus, the overall structure of 1 may be described as adjacent dimeric {Cd(tetrazole)}2 layers that are further supported by the phenylcarboxylate groups to yield intricate 3-D network structure.Note that 1 is a unique 4,4-connected three-dimensional framework with an unprecedented topology (Fig. 3). In this simplification, the green 4-connected nodes are Cd(II) centers and the black are the 4-connected tzba2- ligand. The distances between the connected nodes are 4.314, 4.903, 5.561, and 7.090 Å. Furthermore, the Cd(II) centers are connected by tzba2- ligands to form a 3D open framework with multi-channels (Figs. 4, 5). The helical channels A and B are observed along the a axis, in which {Cd(tetrazole)}4 clusters and double phenylcarboxylate groups are intertwisted in an alternating fashion to form the A channels. The B channel appears to have an 18-membered aperture. In fact, there is no closed 18-membered present in the structure. The unclosed Cd-tetrazole and Cd-tzba are linked to give rise to right-handed helices (Fig. 4). The screw pitch of the helix is 12.48 Å. The C Channels have a 6-membered aperture that are stacked in hexagonal configurations of approximately 8.158 × 5.810 Å along the crystallographic b axis (with Cd1-Cd1 distances of 8.158 and N3-N3 5.810 Å) (Fig. 5).IR Absorption SpectrometryThe IR spectrum of the 1 is shown in Fig. S2. The band at 3,343 cm-1 is assigned to the OH stretching vibration of the carboxyl group. The characteristic band at 1,700 cm-1 is assigned to the νC=O stretching vibration. The band at 1,600 cm-1 is attributed to νC=C in the carboxyl group; and, the band at 1,348 cm-1 is assigned to νC-O. Bands at 1,525 cm-1 and 1,420 cm-1 belong to the tetrazolate ring and the band at 682 cm-1 is the out-of-plane swing vibration of benzene ring and hydrogen [23].TGATo study the thermal stability of 1, TGA was performed (Fig. S3). There are two weight-loss steps from 25 to 800 °C. The first weight-loss (5.4 %) from 60 to 250 °C corresponds to the release of one coordinated water (calcd. 5.69 %). The second weight-loss step (58.82 %) from 400 to 800 °C is attributed to the loss of a tzba ligand (calcd. 58.80 %).PXRD PatternsThe powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of 1 is shown in Fig. S4. The peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD pattern at 20 °C are in agreement, which suggests a good phase purity for 1.Fluorescent PropertyThe solid-state luminescence for 1 was carried out at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the 1 is depicted in Fig. S5. Polymer 1 exhibits a strong blue photoluminescence with emission maxima at 428 nm upon excitations at 376 nm. This is a red shift with respect to the free ligand, H2tzba (λem = 327 nm with excitation at 300 nm [27]). Other tetrazolate-based complexes, such as [Mn(4-TZBA2-)(H2O)2] and [Mn4(4-TZBA2-)4(μ2-H2O)2(H2O) (py)], are bathochromically shifted to 434 nm (excitation at 361 nm) and 425 nm (excitation at 358 nm), respectively. The photoluminescent mechanism is attributed to a ligand-centered π-π* excitation mainly through the aromatic rings of tbza2-, which is characteristic of fluorescent emissions for Cd(II) complexes with other heterocyclic aromatic ligands [24]. The results suggest that the polymer may be used as a blue light-emitting material [1].Sorption PropertiesThe porosity of 1 was estimated by methanol, ethanol and water gas adsorption isotherms at 298 K. As shown in Fig. 6, 1 exhibits Type-I behavior with a small hysteresis to water and methanol. The amount of water and methanol uptake increases with an increase in P/P0 and reaches 165 cm3 g-1 at P/P0 = 0.86. The saturated sorption amount of water is equivalent to the adsorption of about 5.8 mmol g-1. The sorption amount reaches 120 cm3 g-1 at P/P0 = 0.9, which is equivalent to the adsorption of about 4.4 mmol g-1. In contrast, the amount of ethanol sorption (2.3 cm3 g-1 at P/P0 = 0.9) is close to the surface adsorption and is negligible, which indicates that methanol cannot easily enter the channel. Polymer 1 can adsorb water and methanol molecules, but excludes the larger ethanol molecules. The above adsorption studies show that 1 is a promising material for separating methanol and water from bioethanol. Significant hysteresis between adsorption and desorption traces indicates a microporous material [1].ConclusionA novel microporous coordination polymer, [Cd(tbza)(H2O)]n (1), with aromatic spacer-containing ligand tbza2- was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The structure of 1 contains octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four tbza2- ligands to form infinite 3D open framework with multi-channels. Polymer 1 exhibits remarkable selective adsorption behavior; e.g., adsorbs water and methanol, but excludes ethanol. This indicates that 1 is a good porous material for separating both methanol and water from bioethanol. Polymer 1 also displays strong blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of aromatic rings in tbza2- ligand.Crystallographic and Supplementary InformationCCDC 881998 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. elements.content: An unusual tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymer, [Cd(4-tzba)(H2O)]n (tzba = 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid) (1), was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The structure of 1 contains distorted octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four different tzba2− ligands and a water molecule. All the tzba2− ligands display coordination of type, μ4-κN1:κN3:κN4:κO1, O2, which connects four Cd(II) atoms to form an intricate 3-D network. There are three kinds of apertures in the structure of 1; two helical channels and a hexagonal aperture are observed along different axes. Polymer 1 exhibits selective gas adsorption behavior for methanol, ethanol and water. In addition, 1 shows blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of the aromatic rings in the tbza2− ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

An unusual tetrazole-based Cd(II) coordination polymer, [Cd(4-tzba)(H2O)]n (tzba = 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid) (1), was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The structure of 1 contains distorted octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four different tzba2- ligands and a water molecule. All the tzba2- ligands display coordination of type, μ4-κN1:κN3:κN4:κO1, O2, which connects four Cd(II) atoms to form an intricate 3-D network. There are three kinds of apertures in the structure of 1; two helical channels and a hexagonal aperture are observed along different axes. Polymer 1 exhibits selective gas adsorption behavior for methanol, ethanol and water. In addition, 1 shows blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of the aromatic rings in the tbza2- ligand.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great interest not only due to fascinating structural topologies but also for their potential applications in catalysis [1], hydrogen storage [2, 3], adsorption [4, 5], luminescent function [6, 7], magnetism [8], and biomedicine [9]. Construction of desired MOF-extended assemblies involves the selection and design of appropriate organic bridging ligands and metal-connecting nodes. On one hand, organic ligands play crucial roles in the construction of MOFs because changes in flexibility, length and symmetry of the organic ligands can dramatically influence microstructure and the character of resulting coordination polymer [10–20]. Bifunctional organic ligands such as 5-substituted tetrazoles-carboxylates comprise four N-atoms in the tetrazolate and two O-atoms in the carboxyl as potential binding center. These can serve as excellent multidentate ligands and can display complicated coordination modes. Recently, a number of MOFs based on a variety of tetrazoles ligands have been reported [21–29]. However, in contrast to tetrazolate-5-carboxylate coordination polymers composed of acyclic spacers, research on aromatic spacer-containing ligands remains quite rare. For example, 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid ligand-modified MOFs (Scheme S1) are relatively undeveloped. To our knowledge, only rare examples of such coordination polymers have been reported [27, 30]. Thus, 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid simultaneously possesses a rigid and multidentate character (Scheme 1) and may induce new MOFs microporous materials with fascinating architectures [31–35].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great interest not only due to fascinating structural topologies but also for their potential applications in catalysis [1], hydrogen storage [2, 3], adsorption [4, 5], luminescent function [6, 7], magnetism [8], and biomedicine [9]. Construction of desired MOF-extended assemblies involves the selection and design of appropriate organic bridging ligands and metal-connecting nodes. On one hand, organic ligands play crucial roles in the construction of MOFs because changes in flexibility, length and symmetry of the organic ligands can dramatically influence microstructure and the character of resulting coordination polymer [10-20]. Bifunctional organic ligands such as 5-substituted tetrazoles-carboxylates comprise four N-atoms in the tetrazolate and two O-atoms in the carboxyl as potential binding center. These can serve as excellent multidentate ligands and can display complicated coordination modes. Recently, a number of MOFs based on a variety of tetrazoles ligands have been reported [21-29]. However, in contrast to tetrazolate-5-carboxylate coordination polymers composed of acyclic spacers, research on aromatic spacer-containing ligands remains quite rare. For example, 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid ligand-modified MOFs (Scheme S1) are relatively undeveloped. To our knowledge, only rare examples of such coordination polymers have been reported [27, 30]. Thus, 4-(tetrazolyl)benzenecarboxylic acid simultaneously possesses a rigid and multidentate character (Scheme 1) and may induce new MOFs microporous materials with fascinating architectures [31-35].

elements.content: Transition metal Cd(II) ions, due to their relatively strong coordination ability to both O- and N-atoms and various coordination numbers, have been widely used as metal-connecting nodes to construct MOFs. In addition, cadmium ions are excellent candidates for photoluminescence owing to its d [10] electronic configuration [23, 36, 37]. These potential applications further stimulated our interest in the species of the Cd-based MOFs compounds. Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structure and luminescent property of a novel 3D open microporous MOF with multi-shaped channel; i.e., [Cd(tzba)(H2O)] (1). Additionally, the adsorption of methanol, ethanol and water is measured.

These potential applications further stimulated our interest in the species of the Cd-based MOFs compounds. Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structure and luminescent property of a novel 3D open microporous MOF with multi-shaped channel; i.e., [Cd(tzba)(H2O)] (1). Additionally, the adsorption of methanol, ethanol and water is measured.

Experimental

Materials and Measurements

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded from 400 to 4,000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer as pressed KBr pellets. Thermogravimetry (TGA) was performed with a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRD) were collected with a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer using graphite monochromatized CuKα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ from 5 to 50°. The photoluminescent properties were measured with a FLSP920 Edinburgh Fluorescence Spectrometer. The vapor adsorption measurements were performed with an Autosorb-iQ2-MP-AG.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the P21/c space group and exhibits a 3D network joined by the Cd(II) centers and tzba2− ligands. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Cd atom, one tzba2− ligand and one water molecule (Figs. 1, S1). The environment around the six-coordinated Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron with N3B, N4C, O1, and O2 atoms from three different tzba2− ligands constituting the equatorial plane. The axial sites are occupied by water O-atoms (O3) and N1A atoms from the fourth tzba2− ligands with O(3)–Cd(1)–N(1) angle of 169.56(6). The Cd–O bond lengths range from 2.2227(18) to 2.4797(17) Å ; and, the Cd–N bond lengths are 2.3252(17) and 2.3724(18) Å, respectively. All the tzba2− ligands display a type of coordination, μ4-κN1: κN3: κN4: κO1, O2, to connect four Cd(II) atoms with carboxylate group in a bidentate chelating mode and a tetrazolate group in a 1,2,4-N mode. Interestingly, this μ4—bridging mode for the tzba2− ligand is different from those of structurally related tzf2− or tza2− ligands, [40, 41] which was first found in Cd(II) complexes.

Results and Discussion

Structure

The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Cd atom, one tzba2- ligand and one water molecule (Figs. 1, S1). The environment around the six-coordinated Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron with N3B, N4C, O1, and O2 atoms from three different tzba2- ligands constituting the equatorial plane. The axial sites are occupied by water O-atoms (O3) and N1A atoms from the fourth tzba2- ligands with O(3)-Cd(1)-N(1) angle of 169.56(6). The Cd-O bond lengths range from 2.2227(18) to 2.4797(17) Å ; and, the Cd-N bond lengths are 2.3252(17) and 2.3724(18) Å, respectively. All the tzba2- ligands display a type of coordination, μ4-κN1: κN3: κN4: κO1, O2, to connect four Cd(II) atoms with carboxylate group in a bidentate chelating mode and a tetrazolate group in a 1,2,4-N mode. Interestingly, this μ4-bridging mode for the tzba2- ligand is different from those of structurally related tzf2- or tza2- ligands, [40, 41] which was first found in Cd(II) complexes.

elements.content: As shown in Fig. 2a, each tetrazolate group of tzba2− ligand is linked to three Cd(II) atoms and each Cd(II) atom is coordinated to adjacent three tetrazolate groups to form a layer along the bc plane (Fig. 2a), in which two Cd(II) atoms are connected by two tetrazolate groups to form a dimeric cluster; i.e., {Cd(tetrazole)}2 units. The adjacent dimeric units are bonded together in ABAB mode via Cd–N bonds. Moreover, the adjacent dimeric layers are further aggregated through phenylcarboxylate groups along the ac side (Fig. 2b). Thus, the overall structure of 1 may be described as adjacent dimeric {Cd(tetrazole)}2 layers that are further supported by the phenylcarboxylate groups to yield intricate 3-D network structure.

elements.content: Note that 1 is a unique 4,4-connected three-dimensional framework with an unprecedented topology (Fig. 3). In this simplification, the green 4-connected nodes are Cd(II) centers and the black are the 4-connected tzba2− ligand. The distances between the connected nodes are 4.314, 4.903, 5.561, and 7.090 Å. Furthermore, the Cd(II) centers are connected by tzba2− ligands to form a 3D open framework with multi-channels (Figs. 4, 5). The helical channels A and B are observed along the a axis, in which {Cd(tetrazole)}4 clusters and double phenylcarboxylate groups are intertwisted in an alternating fashion to form the A channels. The B channel appears to have an 18-membered aperture. In fact, there is no closed 18-membered present in the structure. The unclosed Cd–tetrazole and Cd–tzba are linked to give rise to right-handed helices (Fig. 4). The screw pitch of the helix is 12.48 Å. The C Channels have a 6-membered aperture that are stacked in hexagonal configurations of approximately 8.158 × 5.810 Å along the crystallographic b axis (with Cd1–Cd1 distances of 8.158 and N3–N3 5.810 Å) (Fig. 5).

elements.content: The IR spectrum of the 1 is shown in Fig. S2. The band at 3,343 cm−1 is assigned to the OH stretching vibration of the carboxyl group. The characteristic band at 1,700 cm−1 is assigned to the νC=O stretching vibration. The band at 1,600 cm−1 is attributed to νC=C in the carboxyl group; and, the band at 1,348 cm−1 is assigned to νC–O. Bands at 1,525 cm−1 and 1,420 cm−1 belong to the tetrazolate ring and the band at 682 cm−1 is the out-of-plane swing vibration of benzene ring and hydrogen [23].

IR Absorption Spectrometry

The IR spectrum of the 1 is shown in Fig. S2. The band at 3,343 cm-1 is assigned to the OH stretching vibration of the carboxyl group. The characteristic band at 1,700 cm-1 is assigned to the νC=O stretching vibration. The band at 1,600 cm-1 is attributed to νC=C in the carboxyl group; and, the band at 1,348 cm-1 is assigned to νC-O. Bands at 1,525 cm-1 and 1,420 cm-1 belong to the tetrazolate ring and the band at 682 cm-1 is the out-of-plane swing vibration of benzene ring and hydrogen [23].

PXRD Patterns

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of 1 is shown in Fig. S4. The peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD pattern at 20 °C are in agreement, which suggests a good phase purity for 1.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence for 1 was carried out at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the 1 is depicted in Fig. S5. Polymer 1 exhibits a strong blue photoluminescence with emission maxima at 428 nm upon excitations at 376 nm. This is a red shift with respect to the free ligand, H2tzba (λem = 327 nm with excitation at 300 nm [27]). Other tetrazolate-based complexes, such as [Mn(4-TZBA2−)(H2O)2] and [Mn4(4-TZBA2−)4(μ2-H2O)2(H2O) (py)], are bathochromically shifted to 434 nm (excitation at 361 nm) and 425 nm (excitation at 358 nm), respectively. The photoluminescent mechanism is attributed to a ligand-centered π–π* excitation mainly through the aromatic rings of tbza2−, which is characteristic of fluorescent emissions for Cd(II) complexes with other heterocyclic aromatic ligands [24]. The results suggest that the polymer may be used as a blue light-emitting material [1].

Fluorescent Property

The solid-state luminescence for 1 was carried out at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the 1 is depicted in Fig. S5. Polymer 1 exhibits a strong blue photoluminescence with emission maxima at 428 nm upon excitations at 376 nm. This is a red shift with respect to the free ligand, H2tzba (λem = 327 nm with excitation at 300 nm [27]). Other tetrazolate-based complexes, such as [Mn(4-TZBA2-)(H2O)2] and [Mn4(4-TZBA2-)4(μ2-H2O)2(H2O) (py)], are bathochromically shifted to 434 nm (excitation at 361 nm) and 425 nm (excitation at 358 nm), respectively. The photoluminescent mechanism is attributed to a ligand-centered π-π* excitation mainly through the aromatic rings of tbza2-, which is characteristic of fluorescent emissions for Cd(II) complexes with other heterocyclic aromatic ligands [24]. The results suggest that the polymer may be used as a blue light-emitting material [1].

elements.content: The porosity of 1 was estimated by methanol, ethanol and water gas adsorption isotherms at 298 K. As shown in Fig. 6, 1 exhibits Type-I behavior with a small hysteresis to water and methanol. The amount of water and methanol uptake increases with an increase in P/P0 and reaches 165 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.86. The saturated sorption amount of water is equivalent to the adsorption of about 5.8 mmol g−1. The sorption amount reaches 120 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.9, which is equivalent to the adsorption of about 4.4 mmol g−1. In contrast, the amount of ethanol sorption (2.3 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.9) is close to the surface adsorption and is negligible, which indicates that methanol cannot easily enter the channel. Polymer 1 can adsorb water and methanol molecules, but excludes the larger ethanol molecules. The above adsorption studies show that 1 is a promising material for separating methanol and water from bioethanol. Significant hysteresis between adsorption and desorption traces indicates a microporous material [1].

elements.content: A novel microporous coordination polymer, [Cd(tbza)(H2O)]n (1), with aromatic spacer-containing ligand tbza2− was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The structure of 1 contains octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four tbza2− ligands to form infinite 3D open framework with multi-channels. Polymer 1 exhibits remarkable selective adsorption behavior; e.g., adsorbs water and methanol, but excludes ethanol. This indicates that 1 is a good porous material for separating both methanol and water from bioethanol. Polymer 1 also displays strong blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of aromatic rings in tbza2− ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A novel microporous coordination polymer, [Cd(tbza)(H2O)]n (1), with aromatic spacer-containing ligand tbza2- was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. The structure of 1 contains octahedral cadmium centers coordinated by four tbza2- ligands to form infinite 3D open framework with multi-channels. Polymer 1 exhibits remarkable selective adsorption behavior; e.g., adsorbs water and methanol, but excludes ethanol. This indicates that 1 is a good porous material for separating both methanol and water from bioethanol. Polymer 1 also displays strong blue photoluminescence mainly arising from intraligand transitions of aromatic rings in tbza2- ligand.

cln_elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared by the hydrothermal method: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.1542 g, 0.50 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol), tzba (0.0951 g, 0.5 0 mmol), and deionized water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30-min, then transferred and sealed in a 25 mLTelfon-lined reactor and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water. (yield 30 % based on Cd). Anal. calcd (%) for C8H4CdN4O3: C, 30.35; H, 1.27; N, 17.70; Cd, 35.51. Found: C, 30.37; H, 1.28; N, 17.74; Cd, 35.56.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Compound 1 was prepared by the hydrothermal method: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.1542 g, 0.50 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol), tzba (0.0951 g, 0.5 0 mmol), and deionized water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30-min, then transferred and sealed in a 25 mLTelfon-lined reactor and heated at 180 °C for 5 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, yellow block crystals were filtered and washed with distilled water. (yield 30 % based on Cd). Anal. calcd (%) for C8H4CdN4O3: C, 30.35; H, 1.27; N, 17.70; Cd, 35.51. Found: C, 30.37; H, 1.28; N, 17.74; Cd, 35.56.

cln_elements.content:
To study the thermal stability of 1, TGA was performed (Fig. S3). There are two weight-loss steps from 25 to 800 °C. The first weight-loss (5.4 %) from 60 to 250 °C corresponds to the release of one coordinated water (calcd. 5.69 %). The second weight-loss step (58.82 %) from 400 to 800 °C is attributed to the loss of a tzba ligand (calcd. 58.80 %).

Fluorescent Property

The solid-state luminescence for 1 was carried out at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the 1 is depicted in Fig. S5. Polymer 1 exhibits a strong blue photoluminescence with emission maxima at 428 nm upon excitations at 376 nm. This is a red shift with respect to the free ligand, H2tzba (λem = 327 nm with excitation at 300 nm [27]). Other tetrazolate-based complexes, such as [Mn(4-TZBA2−)(H2O)2] and [Mn4(4-TZBA2−)4(μ2-H2O)2(H2O) (py)], are bathochromically shifted to 434 nm (excitation at 361 nm) and 425 nm (excitation at 358 nm), respectively. The photoluminescent mechanism is attributed to a ligand-centered π–π* excitation mainly through the aromatic rings of tbza2−, which is characteristic of fluorescent emissions for Cd(II) complexes with other heterocyclic aromatic ligands [24]. The results suggest that the polymer may be used as a blue light-emitting material [1].

Sorption Properties

The porosity of 1 was estimated by methanol, ethanol and water gas adsorption isotherms at 298 K. As shown in Fig. 6, 1 exhibits Type-I behavior with a small hysteresis to water and methanol. The amount of water and methanol uptake increases with an increase in P/P0 and reaches 165 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.86. The saturated sorption amount of water is equivalent to the adsorption of about 5.8 mmol g−1. The sorption amount reaches 120 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.9, which is equivalent to the adsorption of about 4.4 mmol g−1. In contrast, the amount of ethanol sorption (2.3 cm3 g−1 at P/P0 = 0.9) is close to the surface adsorption and is negligible, which indicates that methanol cannot easily enter the channel. Polymer 1 can adsorb water and methanol molecules, but excludes the larger ethanol molecules. The above adsorption studies show that 1 is a promising material for separating methanol and water from bioethanol. Significant hysteresis between adsorption and desorption traces indicates a microporous material [1].
